ohns Hopkins gave Navy one
)1 the most severe football jolts the
Middies have ever received, when
last Saturday afternoon at Annapolis the Black and Blue eleven held
its opponents to a 7 to 3 score, and
came within an ace of winning the
game. Before the game, everything pointed towards an easy victory for the Annapolitans. They
outweighed the Hopkins players by
at least fifteen pounds to a man,
and started football practice about
two weeks earlier, with every man
in the squad reporting on the first
day. The victory is of small credit
to the Navy team under these circumstances, and with the exception
of being saved at the last moment
from the ignominy of defeat at the
hands of Hopkins, the Middies can
derive little consolation from the
result.
Captain Gillett put Hopkins in the
lead early in the first quarter, by
drop-kicking a field goal from the
25-yard line, after Hopkins had
secured the pigskin within striking
distance of the Middie's goal, as
a rrsult of a fumble and several
misplays on the part of Navy players. Navy then tried to carry the
ball through the Hopkins line by
sheer weight. Although Navy
made first downs at various times
throughout the game by line plunging, the Hopkins defence was strong
enough to prevent Navy from
steadily advancing the ball by this
means.
After scoring the field goal, Hopkins was on the defense most of the
time, and put up one of the gamest
fights ever seen at Annapolis. Time
and again, after bertng blocked at
every turn by the comparatively
light Hopkins line, the future admirals were forced to resort to
punting. Alexander and Ccillins of
the Navy eleven made a number of
excellent punts during the game,
and the Hopkins backfield handled
the kicks very poorly. Under anything -like an even break of luck the
Navy team would have gained on
almost all the exchanges of punts,
but after misjudging kicks, the Hopkins backs usually secured the ball
owing to lucky bounces of the p;gskin after striking the gridiron.
The first half ended with the
score still 3 to o. The Hopkins
rooters who had journeyed to the
State capital to see the game could
hardly believe what they had seen
with their eyes, and the Middies
seemed dazed and lifeless. The

Once again the Y. M. C. A.flung
open its hospitable doors to welcom.the new students to their new life
at Hopkins. Once again a feast
was spread, worthy of the gods, but
what's much more practical just
about suited to the taste of everybody present. But before the doors
of. the inner room, where the ice
cream and cake were laid out, were
thrown open, the students present

There is a much larger squad at
Homewood every , afternoon than
has ever been known in the history
of Hopkins football. Most of the
credit for this big showing is due
the classes of 1914 and 1916. The
juniors have nine representatives
on the field, and the freshmen fourteen. The 1916 men deserve a good
deal of credit for the show they
are making, and the sophies will

On Thursday evening, the Y. M.
C. A. of the Medical School held its
annual reception to the incoming
class. Upon enterinc, the lobby,
each man was labelled with his
name and class, after which he proceeded to get acquainted with the
many whom he did not know, girls
included, for at the Medical School
co-eds are invited to Y. M. C. A.
receptions. This looks odd to the
new men, but they soon get used to
them. About 9.30 the real enjoyment began, for as President Remsen said in the first speech of the
evening: "Speech-making is the
American way of having a good
time." He also stated that the University was going to move to
Homewood and would no doubt be
there by the time the entering class
graduated. The real significance
of this remark can only be appreciated by a Hopkins undergraduate
of an upper class. He was followed
by Dean Williams, Dr. Kelly, Dr.
Finney and Dr. Howell, all of
whom, by their wit, thoroughly
mixed with good, sound advice,
made the men feel glad they had
come.
Possibly the strongest and most
important thing said, was when Dr.
Kelly stated that if a student during his four years at the Medical
School threw off the spiritual ties
of his earlier life, he lost what was
worth more to him than anything
lie could possibly gain while there,
no matter if when he graduated he
was pronounced the most brilliant
scholar who had ever received a
(liploma.
Another thing mentioned was that
the present entering class is the
first to be selected from a larger
number of applicants—the class being limited to ninety-five.
A point from Dean Williams'
speech of interest to all Hopkins
men was that because the Medical
School is just as much a part of
the University as the Graduate
School or any other branch, the
medical students are therefore entitled to play on University teams,
and he stated that within reason the
medical faculty not only tolerated
such a diversion from study but
urged the students to go out for
the teams.
Mr. Faust closed the talks by a
statement of the works of the Y.
M. C. A. and the part which should
be taken by the students.
The evening closed with a general
good time in the way of a feed and
dance

A New American Poet.

William Chase Greene, son of
Prof. H. E. Greene, a Rhodes
scholar from Massachusetts, is the
first citizen of the United States
to win that much coveted Oxford
distinction known as the Newdigate prize for English verse, which
he secured with a poem on the subject of Richard I Before Jerusalem.
The English press speaks well of
the production. The founder of
this famous annual prize for poetry
was Sir Roger Newdigate, who
died in 1806, and was a scholar of
considerable excellence. A glance
through the list of winners durinothe more than a century since the
establishment of this prize reveals
the fact that the honor has been
secured by very few who have subsequently risen to great eminence
in the field of letters. It is worth
while, however, to be placed in the
same class with such men as Principal Shairp, Dean Stanley, Dean
Milman, F. W. Faber, John Ruskin, Matthew Arnold, John Addington Symonds and Edwin Arnold.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 7, 1912
Welcome.

We extend our most cordial welcome to the Class of 1916—the
newly arrived baby of the house.
May it grow up to the dignity of
its senior year without losing any
of that numerical strength in which
it is so superior to all its predecessors. We wish '16 the best of
luck; and we want to give it a
few words of parental advice. Let
each bouncing freshman take these
words well to heart.
Our first admonition is perhaps
hardly necessary—don't spend all
your time on your studies. The
other fellows won't, and if you
do, you'll merely cut yourself off
from them, fail to get to know
them well, and lose that most important part of any preparation for
life—a knowledge of human nature.
Go out for an activity—football, if
your are husky enough; lacrosse, if
you are lean and agile; THE NEWSLETTER or the Literary Society, if
you are better provided with brains
than muscles.
But never forget this—and too
many college men have forgotten
it in the past—the activities are not
the principal part of college life.
You have come to Hopkins to become an educated man. Don't neglect your studies. Learn how to
think as well as how to act. Your
studies at college will not be, for
the most part, the mechanical subjects of the high school curriculum,
which require only an exercise of
the memory. They will not only
make it necessary for you to think,
but they will teach you how to
think, and you will find that in the
last analysis, ability to think is
equally as valuable as a knowledge
of human nature.

What the Odds and Ends of 1912 Are
Doing.

D. K. Belt, manager extraordinary, is back from his wheel trip
through Europe. and has been seen
around the University. Donald
confesses that he doesn't just know
what business to engage in, but
that he is thinking over several
things.
Alfred C. Hatch is working at
real estate and insurance; besides,
he has ann3unced his engagement
to be married.
Europe still seems to have special
attractions for Freddie Lee—he is
said to have been last seen "fussing" through Germany—although
he intends to take some graduate
studies at the Hopkins.
Lindsay Rogers, who was editorin-chief of THE NEWS-LETTER during 1912, is working at political
economy in the University and taking a law course at the University
of Maryland.
The banking business has claimed
Gerhard Schmeisser. He is now
with Middendorf, Williams & Co.
William E. Harrison has definitely decided to go into the ministry and is now pursuing a course
at the theological school of the Boston University.
"Jack" Fulton is executive secretary for the National Congress of
Hygiene, now in session at Washington.
T. Brooke Price is at home thinking up what to do.
Hamilton Graham Du Bois will

What Might Have Happened, But Didn't,
the Last Day Hopkins Students Ever
Used Hill's Rhetoric in Eng. I.
(Apologies to Alphonse Daudet.)

That morning I was very late to
school, and was terribly afraid of
getting a zip, for Dr. French had
said he intended to examine us on
solecisms, and I did not know a
word about them:• The thought
came unto my head that I would
cut the class all together; and so
out I went into the alley.
The weather was hot and clear!
One could hear the nickels ringing on the edge of the curb; in
the gym, behind the barred windows, Uhler and Getz were exercising. All this attracted me much
more than the rules about solecisms;
but I had strength to resist and ran
quickly into McCoy Hall.
In passing before the blackboard
in the basement, where notices are
posted, I saw a number of fellows
stopping. I thought to myself
without stopping, "What can it be
now?" Then, as I was runnng
through the basement, the barber,
Walter, who was there with Sam,
on his way to read the notice, cried
out to me: "Don't be in such a
hurry, sir, you will be quite early
enough for your class."
I thought he was making fun of

rile; and I was quite out of breath
when I got to the second-floor hall.
Through the open door of Room
II I could see my comrades already
in their places, and Dr. French, who
had spread out his notes on his
desk. I noticed that he had on his
dress suit, which, till that day, he
had not worn, except when he intended addressing the Woman's
Literary Club of Roland Park.
"Gentlemen," he said, "this is the
last time that I shall teach you Hill's
Rhetoric. The order has come
from the authorities that only
Brewster's English Composition is
to be taught in this class henceforward. The new books arrive tomorrow. Today is your last lesson in Hill. I shall ask you to be
very attentive."
Ah, the wretch! This, then, was
what had been posted in the basement.
My last lesson in Hill! How I
longed for the wasted time, for the
classes I had cut to promenade
Charles street, or to go to the
Alcazar. The book which I usuairy found so dry, so heavy to carry,
now seemed to me an old friend
with whom I was very sorry to
part.
Then, after speaking of one thing
and 'another, Dr. French began to
talk to us about Hill's Rhetoric,saying that it was the most logical in the
world, the clearest, best in technique.
The lecture finished, we passed to
writing a theme on the spire of the
First Church. From time to time,
when I raised my eyes from the
page, I saw Dr. French motionless
in his chair, looking fixedly at his
Hill, as if he would like to absorb
in his eyes the very letters of the
book. Think of it! For seven
years he had taught the same book,
and he had studied out of it himself. What a heart-break it must be
for this poor man to leave his
book! All the same, what courage
he had to carry out the class to
the end!
Suddenly the ten-minutes-of bell
sounded, then the hour. At the
same moment, the tramp of the students changing classes was heard.
Dr. French rose from his chair,
turning very pale. Never had he
looked so tall.
"My friends," he said, "my
friends, I—I." But something
choked him. He could not finish
the sentence. Then he turned to the
blackboard, took a piece of chalk,
and pressing with all his might, he
wrote as large as he could: "Long
Live Hill."
Then he remained there, leaning
his head against the wall, and, without speaking, with his hand made
the sign to us: "All is over; you
G. Y. R.
may go."

summer preparing a set of lectures
to be delivered at Northwestern
University next February. For
several weeks he was at Hot
Springs, Va.

ARBITRATION SOCIETY MEETS

Y. M. C. A. WELCOMES STUDENTS

308 N. CHARLES STREET

Plans Made for the Coming Year Justice
O'Neill Will Address Society Next
Thursday in Donovan Room.

(Continued from page 1.)

SCHOOL AND COLLEGE

TEXT BOOKS

Never Closed

The officers of the Arbitration
Literary Society returned to the
University with coats off and sleeves
rolled up, ready to jump in and work
to make this year of the Arbitration Literary Society's existence the
most successful it has yet enjoyed.
At a meeting, held last Thursday,
it was decided to invite prominent
men and women of this and other
cities to speak before the Society
on important modern problems. The
Society is especially pleased to have
as its first speaker, Mr. J. T.
O'Neill, for several years justice
of.the Eastern Police Station. Mr.
O'Neill will tell of his experience
in East Baltimore. All those who
have heard him speak say that he
is intensely interesting. It is planned
to have a rousing meeting to show
Mr. O'Neill how much Hopkins
students appreciate his kindness in
missing his lunch hour to speak to
the Society. On the twenty-fourth,
Miss Edith Hamilton, president of
the Bryn Mawr School, will address the Society on woman's suffrage. The Society extends a cordial invitation to every one connected with Hopkins to attend both
these meetings.

)1 the most severe football jolts the
Middies have ever received, when
last Saturday afternoon at Annapolis the Black and Blue eleven held
its opponents to a 7 to 3 score, and
came within an ace of winning the
game. Before the game, everything pointed towards an easy victory for the Annapolitans. They
outweighed the Hopkins players by
at least fifteen pounds to a man,
and started football practice about
two weeks earlier, with every man
in the squad reporting on the first
day. The victory is of small credit
to the Navy team under these circumstances, and with the exception
of being saved at the last moment
from the ignominy of defeat at the
hands of Hopkins, the Middies can
derive little consolation from the
result.
Captain Gillett put Hopkins in the
lead early in the first quarter, by
drop-kicking a field goal from the
25-yard line, after Hopkins had
secured the pigskin within striking
distance of the Middie's goal, as
a rrsult of a fumble and several
misplays on the part of Navy players. Navy then tried to carry the
ball through the Hopkins line by
sheer weight. Although Navy
made first downs at various times
throughout the game by line plunging, the Hopkins defence was strong
enough to prevent Navy from
steadily advancing the ball by this
means.
After scoring the field goal, Hopkins was on the defense most of the
time, and put up one of the gamest
fights ever seen at Annapolis. Time
and again, after bertng blocked at
every turn by the comparatively
light Hopkins line, the future admirals were forced to resort to
punting. Alexander and Ccillins of
the Navy eleven made a number of
excellent punts during the game,
and the Hopkins backfield handled
the kicks very poorly. Under anything -like an even break of luck the
Navy team would have gained on
almost all the exchanges of punts,
but after misjudging kicks, the Hopkins backs usually secured the ball
owing to lucky bounces of the p;gskin after striking the gridiron.
The first half ended with the
score still 3 to o. The Hopkins
rooters who had journeyed to the
State capital to see the game could
hardly believe what they had seen
with their eyes, and the Middies
seemed dazed and lifeless. The

On Thursday evening, the Y. M.
C. A. of the Medical School held its
annual reception to the incoming
class. Upon enterinc, the lobby,
each man was labelled with his
name and class, after which he proceeded to get acquainted with the
many whom he did not know, girls
included, for at the Medical School
co-eds are invited to Y. M. C. A.
receptions. This looks odd to the
new men, but they soon get used to
them. About 9.30 the real enjoyment began, for as President Remsen said in the first speech of the
evening: "Speech-making is the
American way of having a good
time." He also stated that the University was going to move to
Homewood and would no doubt be
there by the time the entering class
graduated. The real significance
of this remark can only be appreciated by a Hopkins undergraduate
of an upper class. He was followed
by Dean Williams, Dr. Kelly, Dr.
Finney and Dr. Howell, all of
whom, by their wit, thoroughly
mixed with good, sound advice,
made the men feel glad they had
come.
Possibly the strongest and most
important thing said, was when Dr.
Kelly stated that if a student during his four years at the Medical
School threw off the spiritual ties
of his earlier life, he lost what was
worth more to him than anything
lie could possibly gain while there,
no matter if when he graduated he
was pronounced the most brilliant
scholar who had ever received a
(liploma.
Another thing mentioned was that
the present entering class is the
first to be selected from a larger
number of applicants—the class being limited to ninety-five.
A point from Dean Williams'
speech of interest to all Hopkins
men was that because the Medical
School is just as much a part of
the University as the Graduate
School or any other branch, the
medical students are therefore entitled to play on University teams,
and he stated that within reason the
medical faculty not only tolerated
such a diversion from study but
urged the students to go out for
the teams.
Mr. Faust closed the talks by a
statement of the works of the Y.
M. C. A. and the part which should
be taken by the students.
The evening closed with a general
good time in the way of a feed and
dance

A New American Poet.

William Chase Greene, son of
Prof. H. E. Greene, a Rhodes
scholar from Massachusetts, is the
first citizen of the United States
to win that much coveted Oxford
distinction known as the Newdigate prize for English verse, which
he secured with a poem on the subject of Richard I Before Jerusalem.
The English press speaks well of
the production. The founder of
this famous annual prize for poetry
was Sir Roger Newdigate, who
died in 1806, and was a scholar of
considerable excellence. A glance
through the list of winners durinothe more than a century since the
establishment of this prize reveals
the fact that the honor has been
secured by very few who have subsequently risen to great eminence
in the field of letters. It is worth
while, however, to be placed in the
same class with such men as Principal Shairp, Dean Stanley, Dean
Milman, F. W. Faber, John Ruskin, Matthew Arnold, John Addington Symonds and Edwin Arnold.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 7, 1912
Welcome.

We extend our most cordial welcome to the Class of 1916—the
newly arrived baby of the house.
May it grow up to the dignity of
its senior year without losing any
of that numerical strength in which
it is so superior to all its predecessors. We wish '16 the best of
luck; and we want to give it a
few words of parental advice. Let
each bouncing freshman take these
words well to heart.
Our first admonition is perhaps
hardly necessary—don't spend all
your time on your studies. The
other fellows won't, and if you
do, you'll merely cut yourself off
from them, fail to get to know
them well, and lose that most important part of any preparation for
life—a knowledge of human nature.
Go out for an activity—football, if
your are husky enough; lacrosse, if
you are lean and agile; THE NEWSLETTER or the Literary Society, if
you are better provided with brains
than muscles.
But never forget this—and too
many college men have forgotten
it in the past—the activities are not
the principal part of college life.
You have come to Hopkins to become an educated man. Don't neglect your studies. Learn how to
think as well as how to act. Your
studies at college will not be, for
the most part, the mechanical subjects of the high school curriculum,
which require only an exercise of
the memory. They will not only
make it necessary for you to think,
but they will teach you how to
think, and you will find that in the
last analysis, ability to think is
equally as valuable as a knowledge
of human nature.

What Might Have Happened, But Didn't,
the Last Day Hopkins Students Ever
Used Hill's Rhetoric in Eng. I.
(Apologies to Alphonse Daudet.)

That morning I was very late to
school, and was terribly afraid of
getting a zip, for Dr. French had
said he intended to examine us on
solecisms, and I did not know a
word about them:• The thought
came unto my head that I would
cut the class all together; and so
out I went into the alley.
The weather was hot and clear!
One could hear the nickels ringing on the edge of the curb; in
the gym, behind the barred windows, Uhler and Getz were exercising. All this attracted me much
more than the rules about solecisms;
but I had strength to resist and ran
quickly into McCoy Hall.
In passing before the blackboard
in the basement, where notices are
posted, I saw a number of fellows
stopping. I thought to myself
without stopping, "What can it be
now?" Then, as I was runnng
through the basement, the barber,
Walter, who was there with Sam,
on his way to read the notice, cried
out to me: "Don't be in such a
hurry, sir, you will be quite early
enough for your class."
I thought he was making fun of

rile; and I was quite out of breath
when I got to the second-floor hall.
Through the open door of Room
II I could see my comrades already
in their places, and Dr. French, who
had spread out his notes on his
desk. I noticed that he had on his
dress suit, which, till that day, he
had not worn, except when he intended addressing the Woman's
Literary Club of Roland Park.
"Gentlemen," he said, "this is the
last time that I shall teach you Hill's
Rhetoric. The order has come
from the authorities that only
Brewster's English Composition is
to be taught in this class henceforward. The new books arrive tomorrow. Today is your last lesson in Hill. I shall ask you to be
very attentive."
Ah, the wretch! This, then, was
what had been posted in the basement.
My last lesson in Hill! How I
longed for the wasted time, for the
classes I had cut to promenade
Charles street, or to go to the
Alcazar. The book which I usuairy found so dry, so heavy to carry,
now seemed to me an old friend
with whom I was very sorry to
part.
Then, after speaking of one thing
and 'another, Dr. French began to
talk to us about Hill's Rhetoric,saying that it was the most logical in the
world, the clearest, best in technique.
The lecture finished, we passed to
writing a theme on the spire of the
First Church. From time to time,
when I raised my eyes from the
page, I saw Dr. French motionless
in his chair, looking fixedly at his
Hill, as if he would like to absorb
in his eyes the very letters of the
book. Think of it! For seven
years he had taught the same book,
and he had studied out of it himself. What a heart-break it must be
for this poor man to leave his
book! All the same, what courage
he had to carry out the class to
the end!
Suddenly the ten-minutes-of bell
sounded, then the hour. At the
same moment, the tramp of the students changing classes was heard.
Dr. French rose from his chair,
turning very pale. Never had he
looked so tall.
"My friends," he said, "my
friends, I—I." But something
choked him. He could not finish
the sentence. Then he turned to the
blackboard, took a piece of chalk,
and pressing with all his might, he
wrote as large as he could: "Long
Live Hill."
Then he remained there, leaning
his head against the wall, and, without speaking, with his hand made
the sign to us: "All is over; you
G. Y. R.
may go."

to be delivered at Northwestern
University next February. For
several weeks he was at Hot
Springs, Va.

Y. M. C. A. WELCOMES STUDENTS

308 N. CHARLES STREET

Plans Made for the Coming Year Justice
O'Neill Will Address Society Next
Thursday in Donovan Room.

(Continued from page 1.)

SCHOOL AND COLLEGE

TEXT BOOKS

Never Closed

The officers of the Arbitration
Literary Society returned to the
University with coats off and sleeves
rolled up, ready to jump in and work
to make this year of the Arbitration Literary Society's existence the
most successful it has yet enjoyed.
At a meeting, held last Thursday,
it was decided to invite prominent
men and women of this and other
cities to speak before the Society
on important modern problems. The
Society is especially pleased to have
as its first speaker, Mr. J. T.
O'Neill, for several years justice
of.the Eastern Police Station. Mr.
O'Neill will tell of his experience
in East Baltimore. All those who
have heard him speak say that he
is intensely interesting. It is planned
to have a rousing meeting to show
Mr. O'Neill how much Hopkins
students appreciate his kindness in
missing his lunch hour to speak to
the Society. On the twenty-fourth,
Miss Edith Hamilton, president of
the Bryn Mawr School, will address the Society on woman's suffrage. The Society extends a cordial invitation to every one connected with Hopkins to attend both
these meetings.
